DOC.UNK: News Agency Says Army Confiscated Panama Videotape
DOC.TEXT: An Army soldier confiscated the tape of a TV news agency cameraman who shot pictures Thursday of U.S. troops surrounding the Nicaraguan and Cuban embassies in Panama City, the agency's bureau chief here said. A complaint will be filed with the Pentagon, said Robert Sullivan, bureau chief of Worldwide Television News. Based in London, WTN is co-owned by ABC and includes ABC, CBS and CNN among its clients. Sullivan said the WTN camerman, Alejandro Carbonnel, a Panamanian, was shooting pictures when an U.S. Army sergeant approached him and confiscated the cameraman's videotape. Carbonnel said the soldier gave no explanation other that the cameraman ``had to have permission from the Southern Command to shoot here,'' Sullivan said. He said the sergeant's indentity isn't known.. The Southern Command is the multi-service U.S. military command running the military strike in Panama that was aimed at toppling Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The American troops in Panama City surrounded the Cuban and Nicaruagan embassies there Thursday after rumors spread that Noriega may have fled to one of the embassies during the U.S. military invasion of his country. Carbonel was among the press corps in Panama when the invasion began Wednesday. He is not part of the Pentagon press pool flown there. NBC correspondent Fred Francis is the pool's correspondent for the major networks.
